Docs.summary: Provides a container for a group of commands or controls.

remarks.format:
## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBar> controls provide an overflow mechanism that places items that do not fit on the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBar> into an overflow area. Only toolbar elements within a parent <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBarTray> can be moved or resized by the user.
<xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBar> is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.HeaderedItemsControl>, which means its header and collection of objects can be of any type (such as string, image, or panel). For more information, see the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.HeaderedItemsControl> class.
## Customizing the ToolBar Control To apply the same property settings to multiple <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBar> controls, use the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.Style%2A> property. You can modify the default <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> to give the control a unique appearance. For more information about creating a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate>, see [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/customizing-the-appearance-of-an-existing-control.md). To see the parts and states that are specific to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBar>, see [ToolBar Styles and Templates](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/toolbar-styles-and-templates.md).
Dependency properties for this control might be set by the control's default style. If a property is set by a default style, the property might change from its default value when the control appears in the application. The default style is determined by which desktop theme is used when the application is running. For more information, see [Default WPF Themes](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=158252).
> [!NOTE] > Setting a visual property will only have an effect if that property is both present in <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBar> control's default template and is set by using a . You can find a list of visual properties in the "Changing the Visual Structure of a Control" section in [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/customizing-the-appearance-of-an-existing-control.md).
## Examples The following example shows how to create a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBar> inside a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBarTray>.
[!code-xaml[ToolBarExample#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/ToolBarExample/CS/Pane1.xaml#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int Band { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.Band : int with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates where the toolbar should be located in the .
Docs.value: The band of the in which the toolbar is positioned. The default is 0.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The position of the in a depends on the values of the , , and properties. When is set to , a band represents a row in the . When is , a band represents a column of the . The following table describes the relationship between , , and . |Orientation|Band|BandIndex| |-----------------|----------|---------------| |Horizontal|Indicates the row in which the is positioned. Toolbars that have set to a smaller value are above those with a larger value.|Indicates the position of the on the . Toolbars that have set to a smaller value are to the left of those with a larger value.| |Vertical|Indicates the column in which the is positioned. Toolbars that have set to a smaller value are to the left of those with a larger value.|Indicates the position of the on the . Toolbars that have set to a smaller value are above those with a larger value.| ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|| ## Examples The following example shows how use this property to place controls inside a . [!code-xaml[ToolBarExample#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/ToolBarExample/CS/Pane1.xaml#2)]

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int BandIndex { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.BandIndex : int with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the band index number that indicates the position of the toolbar on the band.
Docs.value: The position of a toolbar on the band of a .

remarks.format: ## Remarks If you do not explicitly set this property, its value is determined by the order in which the is set in the . For example, if you put two toolbars in a without setting the and properties, the value of will be 0 for both toolbars. The value of will be 0 for the first toolbar and 1 for the second toolbar. The position of the in a depends on the values of the , , and properties. When is set to , a band represents a row in the . When is , a band represents a column of the . The following table describes the relationship between , , and . |Orientation|Band|BandIndex| |-----------------|----------|---------------| |Horizontal|Indicates the row in which the is positioned. Toolbars that have set to a smaller value are above those with a larger value.|Indicates the position of the on the . Toolbars that have set to a smaller value are to the left of those with a larger value.| |Vertical|Indicates the column in which the is positioned. Toolbars that have set to a smaller value are to the left of those with a larger value.|Indicates the position of the on the . Toolbars that have set to a smaller value are above those with a larger value.| ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|| ## Examples The following example shows how use this property to place controls inside a . [!code-xaml[ToolBarExample#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/ToolBarExample/CS/Pane1.xaml#2)]

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property HasOverflowItems As Boolean
public: property bool HasOverflowItems { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the toolbar has items that are not visible.
Docs.value: if there are items on the toolbar that are not visible; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks If a has more items than it has the space to show, it puts the remaining items in its overflow area. The user can click the arrow on the to access the overflow items. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Windows.DependencyProperty HasOverflowItemsProperty
Public Shared ReadOnly HasOverflowItemsProperty As DependencyProperty

Docs.summary: Identifies the dependency property.
Gets a value that indicates whether the item is an overflow item.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property is a read-only attached property. Read-only attached properties are uncommon, and have no direct [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)] usage. However, you can use the attached property reference as a property trigger in a style, to apply different style values to an item within a toolbar that is in the overflow panel. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| ## XAML Text Usage See Remarks.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnKeyDown(class System.Windows.Input.KeyEventArgs e) cil managed
Protected Overrides Sub OnKeyDown (e As KeyEventArgs)

Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the routed event that occurs when a key is pressed on an item in the .

remarks.format: ## Remarks When the user presses HOME, the first item in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBar> receives keyboard focus. When the user presses END, the last item in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ToolBar> receives keyboard focus. When this occurs, this implementation marks the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.KeyDown> event as handled by setting the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> property of the event data to `true`.

block.para: If you override , always call the base implementation in your implementation. Failure to call the base implementation prevents base classes from handling the event with a class handler, which might change the run-time behavior of the final class. You can call the base implementation either before or after your special handling, depending on your requirements.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnLostMouseCapture(class System.Windows.Input.MouseEventArgs e) cil managed
Protected Overrides Sub OnLostMouseCapture (e As MouseEventArgs)

Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the routed event that occurs when the loses mouse capture.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This implementation does not change the handled state (the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> property) of the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.LostMouseCapture> event data.

block.para: If you override , always call the base implementation in your implementation. Failure to call the base implementation prevents base classes from handling the event with a class handler, which might change the run-time behavior of the final class. You can call the base implementation either before or after your special handling, depending on your requirements.
